662a29c3b19e.description: A collection of posts by M.G. Siegler of around 500 words.
662a29c3b19e.name: 500ish Words
662a29c3b19e.shortDescription: A collection of posts by M.G. Siegler of around 500 words.

paragraphs.text: It’s still nascent, but other forms of monetization are starting to have some tailwinds. Footholds will be gotten eventually, one way or another. At the same time, the hysteria around fake news and the like is pushing back against advertising at massive scale. A niche network, with a highly targeted user base, can create unique, new advertising options.
paragraphs.name: d5df

paragraphs.text: ¹ “Great” simply meaning “massive” here in terms of scale. Quantity, not necessarily quantity.
paragraphs.name: 69df
d5df
paragraphs.text: It’s still nascent, but other forms of monetization are starting to have some tailwinds. Footholds will be gotten eventually, one way or another. At the same time, the hysteria around fake news and the like is pushing back against advertising at massive scale. A niche network, with a highly targeted user base, can create unique, new advertising options.

paragraphs.name: e362
paragraphs.text: Of course, it’s hard to come out of the gate with a mentality to “go small” — again, meaning here: simply not going after acquiring the most users possible — it requires patience, focus, and a hell of a lot of confidence. And the knowledge that often, big things have small beginnings. Some even aim to start in such a way, with other paths opening up along the journey.
¹ “Great” simply meaning “massive” here in terms of scale. Quantity, not necessarily quantity.
paragraphs.name: 69df

paragraphs.text: If I was to give advice to anyone looking to build a social network right now, it would be pretty simple: go granular. Niche, even. The road to massive scale is closed, but another one has opened. A large percentage of a small base is still small. But a small percentage of a massive base is large.
paragraphs.name: 88ee

paragraphs.text: If I was to give advice to anyone looking to build a social network right now, it would be pretty simple: go granular. Niche, even. The road to massive scale is closed, but another one has opened. A large percentage of a small base is still small. But a small percentage of a massive base is large.
paragraphs.name: 88ee

paragraphs.text: And again, the true competition here is time. The way to attack that is no longer with broad appeal, it’s by way of highly targeted passion.³
paragraphs.name: 0dd9

paragraphs.text: It’s starting to feel more and more like the last “great” social network was Snapchat.¹ It was founded just over five years ago. And, of course, it just went public with over 150 million active users. There have been many other networks that have launched in the intervening years, and some have gotten some nice traction. But, at least in the U.S. market, it feels like the window is shut to reach such a massive scale.
paragraphs.name: 2a7e

paragraphs.text: But, backing up for a second, far more problematic for any new social network is the fact that many people already have the handful of apps they now use in a given day. We’ve reached app saturation. (Which was obvious years ago.) The barrier to entry isn’t building a better or more compelling service — that’s actually not good enough any more. Because the true barrier is the one that ends everything: time.
paragraphs.name: d9d2
da31
paragraphs.text: There’s simply not enough hours in a day for everyone to use every social network out there. And so you have to choose the two or three or four that all your friends are on. And again, those are already established. So you see why this is such a mountain to climb. In the early days of the App Store, the mountain was more of a molehill. Now it’s Mount Everest.

The reason why is both obvious and not. It’s not that these newer networks aren’t as compelling as the ones that came before — some are far better in terms of features, speed, and polish. Certainly, many now start out far better than the networks of yesteryear. But the reality of our current situation is that many countries have reached smartphone saturation. And, as such, many of those users now already have their go-to social networks. They’re the ones we all know.

If I was to give advice to anyone looking to build a social network right now, it would be pretty simple: go granular. Niche, even. The road to massive scale is closed, but another one has opened. A large percentage of a small base is still small. But a small percentage of a massive base is large.
paragraphs.name: 88ee

27ca8fd7f292.title: I’m convinced that your point isn’t limited to social networks.

paragraphs.text: I’m convinced that your point isn’t limited to social networks. At the very least it also applies to all kinds of media. The latter is the first (but probably not the last) industry that arrived at a state of abundance. Yet, that doesn’t equate to cockaigne. Neither for consumers nor companies.

5232c4b17e41.title: Although this statement could be true, IMO the main reason social networks haven’t taken off is a…

paragraphs.text: Although this statement could be true, IMO the main reason social networks haven’t taken off is a lack of initial utility for an individual user. Too many social networks rely on the “if my product reaches critical mass” line for applications that don’t have a strong enough first player tool to have users returning long enough to establish enough…

paragraphs.text: I’ve started to spend more time in Google+ since they removed a lot of the cruft and focused on Collections and Communities. There are Communities with thousands, tens of thousands, or hundreds of thousands, of people with common interests, and engagement seems to be much higher.

84bad2f0e501.title: And, that’s where the true opportunities lie.

paragraphs.text: And, that’s where the true opportunities lie. Highly targeted passion is where the most easily monetized platform users are. There will be more than a few very successful companies built by identifying them and giving them an app that addresses their passion.
paragraphs.name: 38e8

d00527e27fb7.title: I really like your take here, especially when it comes to places like Medium, where the point is to…

paragraphs.text: I really like your take here, especially when it comes to places like Medium, where the point is to share ideas with people who share your passions. Community is important, but at some point a community can become so large that’s it’s not really a community anymore, just an aggregation of people. Bigger is not always better.

Excellent analysis. Really helpful. Something else to think about: the rise of apps that work with all social networks. Apple’s Clips, which I was prepared to hate, is actually very clever in this regard.
paragraphs.name: d02e
